results.title: Poison
results.creator_credit: Todd Haynes, Christine Vachon, Bronze Eye Prod and Zeitgesist Prod
results.brief_description: A film in three parts. In “Hero” a young boy kills his father who is abusing him and then the boy flies out of the window to Heaven. In “Horror” a possibly mad scientist finds he is falling victim to a disease created by his experiments in isolating the essence of the human sex drive. And in “Homo” a brutal prison love affair takes place in a Borstal prison that keeps changing shape and colour. Filmed in contrasting styles, initially seemingly random, the three episodes of “Poison” eventually come together to celebrate cinematic homoeroticism, the history of gay and queer subversion (especially the work of Jean Genet) and to delineate new possibilities for an erotic cinema. Beautifully made, ingeniously constructed and filmed “Poison” is part of a new form of cinema, a “queer cinema” that celebrates new forms of visual pleasure.

results.title: Merce Cunningham & Company
results.creator_credit: Benoit Jacquot, Cunningham Dance Foundation and L'Institut National de L'Audiovisuel (INA)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
This documentary explores Merce Cunningham’s method of choreography, including his employment of random methods through use of the I Ching, his collaboration with composer John Cage and his relationship with the dancers in his Company. Cunningham candidly reveals his ideas on dance through interviews, and footage from rehearsal at the Cunningham studios. Included are dance excerpts from “Trails,” “Scramble,” “Aeon,” “Quartet”, “Suite For Five”, “Roadrunners” and “Fractions”. In English with French with English subtitles. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html
results.creator_credit_for_label: Benoit Jacquot, Cunningham Dance Foundation and L’Institut National de L’Audiovisuel (INA)

results.title: Portraits: New England Fishermen
results.creator_credit: Doug Bears, Contemporary Art Television (CAT) Fund and Joan Logue
results.brief_description: Presented with a straightforward charm, Logue’s abbreviated portraits of fishermen in Gloucester, Massachusetts are more than mere “fish stories”. Seen on their boats in the open sea, the fishermen speak directly to the camera, relating anecdotes and observations that are alternately comic or poignant. Logue documents the fishermen’s individual characters and evokes a sense of their rituals and traditions. With humor and pride, the fishermen chronicle their close ties to family, the ocean, and their community. Logue applies elegant video effects that heighten the resonance of these brief vignettes.

results.title: Lie of the land
results.creator_credit: Barry Pierce, Anne Whitehead and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Maps and Map Reading”.
Using the example of a company setting up a VHF radio network in rugged mountain country, the film examines the lines of sight, gradients and contour patterns. Produced for the State Emergency Service Tasmania.

results.title: Going bush
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Barry Pierce, Anne Whitehead and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Maps and Map Reading”.
If a bushwalking adventure is not to turn into some sort of nightmare then careful planning must be undertaken at the outset. Five bushwalkers plan all aspects of their four day walk before setting off into the wilderness. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Points for survival
results.creator_credit: Barry Pierce, Anne Whitehead and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Maps and Map Reading”.
Correct use of a compass in conjunction with intelligent map-reading illustrates how a bushwalker who had fallen down a cliff is rescued by his wife and a ranger whoa are able to locate him with the aide of map and compass.

results.title: Ground rules
results.creator_credit: Barry Pierce, Anne Whitehead and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Maps and Map Reading”.
An introductory segment that sets out to establish a broad understanding of the use of and need for maps and map reading skills. Three situations are illustrated: an ambulance attending an accident, a car rally navigator planning his route, and two tourists who are hopelessly lost on a back road.

results.title: Chart before the course
results.creator_credit: Barry Pierce, Anne Whitehead and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Maps and Map Reading”.
We follow the mapmaking process from the first aerial photographs through photogrammetric drawings to the final print stage. Among the points discussed are contour lines, grid references and magnetic variations.

results.title: Portrait of the artist as an old lady
results.creator_credit: Gail Singer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Paraskeva Clark, artist, socialist, feminist, is her own woman at her own cost. This film is a cameo of an irascible and oftentimes touching artist whose work has won her a place in exhibitions and private collections. Born in Russia in 1898, she eventually married a Canadian and moved to Toronto. Because her canvases reflect a strong social conscience, she had to struggle hard to earn a place in the nation’s ultra-conservative galleries. With Germaine Greer narrating, this film explores Clarke’s early life through photographs, reminiscences and her painting. (Awards: Montrial, Melbourne)
